awd_titl_txt: Improved locations for global seismic events using surface waves
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will develop new methods for locating earthquakes in remote areas of the world with greater precision. Current methods of earthquake location, based on classical techniques that are used routinely by agencies such as the United States Geological Survey, the International Seismological Centre, and the International Monitoring System, provide no better than 25-km precision in earthquake location in many areas of the world. This lack of precision limits the ability to attribute individual earthquakes to specific earthquake faults, and thus also the possibility to understand better the tectonic context. The project will develop new algorithms based on inter-event correlations of intermediate-period surface waves, and is expected to lead to a location precision of 5 km or better. The algorithm will be used to address questions of plate-boundary tectonics and seismogenesis. The improvements in earthquake location will lead to new data sets with broad utility for research in plate tectonics, plate-boundary processes and global seismic tomography.

The new algorithm is based on cross correlation of surface-wave signals from nearby earthquakes recorded on common stations. Effects of wave propagation between the earthquakes and the stations are canceled out, and the remaining signal is related to the propagation time delay between the stations, and to predictable source effects. The results are improved by correcting for laterally varying dispersion. The approach will make use of all available pairs of Rayleigh and Love waves for a regional cluster of earthquakes to invert for relative locations of all events in the cluster. The cluster will then be anchored to geomorphological features to provide absolute locations of the individual earthquakes.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research is to develop a better method to locate earthquakes in remote areas of the world with greater precision. Current methods of earthquake location, based on classical techniques that are used by agencies such as the United States Geological Survey and the International Seismological Centre in the UK, provide no better than 25-kilometer precision in earthquake location in many areas of the world. This lack of precision limits the ability to attribute individual earthquakes to specific earthquake faults, and thus also the possibility to understand better the tectonic context.

The primary outcome of the research is a method of earthquake location that makes use of the cross correlation of surface waves of shallow earthquakes that occur in close proximity. When hundreds to several thousands of such correlations between tens or hundreds of earthquakes are analyzed simultaneously, highly precise relative locations can be obtained. While similar approaches have been used previously, the new method includes an important correction for differences in the focal mechanisms of the two earthquakes being correlated, which improves the determination of relative locations.

Specific outcomes include the validation of the method when applied to model data and the demonstration that the method provides dramatically improved locations when applied to groups of earthquakes in different seismically active areas.

The accompanying figure shows the improvement in earthquake location achieved when the method is used to locate earthquakes on the East Pacific Rise in the vicinity of the Gofar Transform Fault. The top panel shows the focal mechanisms of the earthquakes plotted at the locations reported in the USGS catalog. Locations in the ISC catalog show an equally diffuse distribution. Neither the USGS nor the ISC  set of locations shows patterns of earthquakes that are consistent with focused deformation along the transform fault. The bottom panel shows the same earthquakes after locating them using the new method developed in this research. The earthquakes line up on distinct segments of the transform fault. Gaps in seismicity are associated with largely aseismic plate separation and extension at mid-oceanic ridge segments.
